"Javlyn," she responded.
"Come on," Javlyn said, feeling cheery.
"names Eldon."
"Seems like you got here just in time," Eldon offered.
"Was hoping to avoid the next downpour," Eldon said.
Eldon looked put out, staring up at the sky in disbelief.
Eldon would survive, and he would do so because she came out today to save him.

Terence sighed heavily, "We probably shouldn't go into the cave with this."

He exited and came to a stop by them, panting.
"F-fine," Terence got out through shivers, then jumped in place a little, "Even with the protection I weaved against cold to wield the blade, that was close."
"There was one creature inside. Tried to charge when it saw me. Threw the sword. Cave is, uh, an ice cave right now. Might want to give it a couple days before you venture back in."

characters.name: Javlyn

mentions.quote: In one corner of the cave, Javlyn found a pile of bones and rags.
She was just crouching to get a closer look when a shuffling noise came echoing down the tunnel.
Immediately standing, Javlyn looked around and realized there was no where to hide.
She rushed to cross the cave, deciding standing right to the side of the exit of the tunnel was her best bet.
She couldn't snuff out the lantern or else she wouldn't be able to see while the monster likely would be able to.
The best she could do was tuck the lantern on the relatively flat ground behind her tucked in near the cavern wall.
She had been noisy, but the shuffling noise hadn't seemed to change.
She tried to step back in front of it, but it was too late.
She dodged to the side and struggled to pull Nivek's sword.
She struck out with the sword twice, and had to duck under the creatures arm swipe.
She lunged forward, catching the monster in the stomach, and pulled back and dodged to the side again.
She rolled away from the victim and scrambled up, finding the monster bearing down on her.
She swung the sword wildly, desperate, and was lucky when it connected across the monsters snout.
She was able to leverage the person up, the arm with the good shoulder thrown over her own with her taking most of their weight.
Near the tunnel, Javlyn looked at the lantern but didn't grab it.
She could come back for it later.
Javlyn settled the man against the cliffside and finally saw him in the light.
She didn't really have anything to wrap the wounds in, but she tore the man's shirt, whispering apologizes as she went, and it worked well enough.
It had started to rain by the time she finished checking the man over.
Standing, she looked around for the donkey he had mentioned.
Down the road towards Furlsby, there was a donkey grazing off the path, laden with packs.
"I'll be right back," Javlyn told the unresponsive man, "Think I found your donkey."
It didn't take much to round up the donkey and convince it to follow.
Just let me get my lantern," Javlyn said, darting back in the cave to retrieve it.
With some difficulty, she managed to get the man laying over the donkey's back.
She kept up the murmuring the entire way back.
As awful as this was, the satisfaction of having saved someone made coming out on this miserable day worth it.

facts: Rescues a man and a donkey
Travels through cave, tunnel, cliffside, Furlsby

Javlyn had to fumble a bit, but she was able to attach the lantern to her belt securely.
It took a couple minutes, but Javlyn was able to climb to the ledge she spotted.
Javlyn untied the lantern and held it out over the edge, hoping to see the water she heard, but nothing but blackness.
After tying the lantern back onto her belt, Javlyn carefully straddled and wormed her way over a rock formation in order to make it onto the ledge.
She might have reached the edge of this cavernous space. Once she could fully stand again she took a moment to shake out her legs before starting again.
Eventually, long enough on that her legs burned from the effort, the floor sloped down and widened, and Javlyn realized the wall was curving.
She might not have found any monsters, but she couldn't wait to return.

mentions.quote: Grouped together at the back of the cave were three, no four creatures. They were focused on something on the ground and almost before she could fully process what she'd seen Javlyn pulled back around the corner.
Javlyn carefully shifted the lantern in hope the light wasn't visible.
Slowly, bit by bit, Javlyn carefully worked her way out of the tunnel away from the cavern.
She took forever, the upmost attention spent to ensure no sound was produced.
Once she was fully outside, she extinguished the lantern and hung it off her belt before sheathing the sword.
Closing her eyes, she tried to figure out what exactly she had seen in there.
Taking a couple steps away she turned and looked at the cave entrance.
Looking over the entrance critically, Javlyn determined she likely could block it.
She couldn't go slow, but the heavy clothing was a hindrance.
She stripped off her jacket, overheated from the climb and immediately went near the cave entrance.
She tried to push, and then scrambled near their base with her fingers trying to do something to help it move.
What she really needed was a shovel, but all she had was that damn sword.
As the rain began to fall, Javlyn grabbed the sword and treated it like a shovel, shifting it back and forth to clear dirt and then tried to use it like a lever.
Javlyn threw the swords handle behind her and threw her shoulder against the boulder, catching it just as the momentum was shifting.
Javlyn stumbled and barely saved herself from following the boulder.
She checked the cave entrance from ground level to make sure, but it was solidly blocked.
Javlyn, after watching for a moment, decided there was nothing else to do and turned and headed home.
She'd hopefully have a better story than she broke the sword trying to move a rock by the time she made it home.
